question: Keep this from getting wet. Go home at late afternoon mealtime and don't come back to work today -- I'll tell the Abbot. Just rest today. You're lucky you only burned yourself on the side of the furnace. If some of that glass had gotten on your arm -- -- it would've burned clean through to the other side. That's late afternoon. Now get on. You're welcome. Go!
answer: Good work.

question: All right, but I'm no Father Anselm.
answer: You're yourself, that's better... The Abbot will be pleased.

question: Don't.
answer: Don't what?

question: Please don't tell him. At least until I know if there's an infection.
answer: You want to be the Abbey's Physician, and you haven't learned the first rule I shouldn't have. Sorry. Look, I know how you must --

question: You don't, but thanks anyway.
answer: Not coming down?

question: I have someone waiting for me. Come on, Mattias. Brother Philip. My training has taught me to feed what's hungry. How could I forget? Have a good meal... Perfect.
answer: Mind? Just Philip, if he knew. I passed him on the way up. He said you'd come in alone. I knew better. Hello, Mattias. How are you, boy? You know what Philip says about Mattias' hair and his breathing. You'll have to take him out of here.

question: He likes when I read to him and -- I can't --
answer: Someone must have left this one unlocked. Take the book with you.

question: Father, I --?
answer: Kyle tells me you did a good job at the glassworks today.

question: I'll reserve judgement until the patient lives.
answer: It will get easier. Father Anselm was... an unexpected loss. You'll do fine. Just have it back before the end of lunch. Oh -- And I didn't see you in here.

question: Thank you. Let's go upstairs, boy. Walks to the shore of an inland SEA. Sits on a bare patch of wood. Looks up. His eyes grow accustomed to -- In the year of our Lord 1348 I, Brother Gerhado of the Minorite Abbey helped bury the Abbot and my sixty fellow monks, day by day, one by one, until I am the only one left. I stayed as long as I could bear it, then with my dog -- - fled. I have put this to parchment lest this pestilence - this Black Death - stay my hand. This was finished by another hand... Joined by three other MONKS. They are older than he. The Four men watch the sky... Is the first to hit the shore. Small leather and wood fishing boats tossed by the wake. His coracle is the first into the water. The others running up behind him. He cannot hear the SHOUTS of warning. Rows right into it. His coracle pitches in the choppy surf. He scrambles onto the ship's cracked tile surface. Teeters -- balances -- moves to the unmistakeable HATCH. Looks around for a knob, a handle --
answer: John! Wait -- ! Don't go in!

question: Looks back towards the door. Part of him wants to get the hell out here -- but he fights back his fear. He is a doctor - or trying to be - someone in here may need his help. He presses forward -- Averts his gaze from the clothing, UP to the blinking and glowing instrument panels and their myraid --
answer: John - what is it? Is this a Supply ship?

question: What the hell --? This must be a dream. A bad one. Hears the SOUND and then another - her door OPENING. She turns to find the Abbot and John standing in the doorway. John waits in the doorway as the Abbot crosses to the chair by the bed and sits. Who are you?
answer: I am the Abbot. Leader of this Colony. And you?

question: Ripley. How did I get here?
answer: Your vehicle crash landed. Brother John found you and brought you here.

question: Where is here?
answer: This is the Minorite Abbey within the manmade orbiter Arceon.

question: Can I use a radio to --
answer: We have no radio here. We are a monastic order that has renounced all modern technology. We live the old way. The pure way.

question: Uh, I - I still don't feel 100%. Whoever took me out of the stasis tube must not have run the full D-F program... Where's Newt? There was a little girl with me --
answer: You were alone.

question: No. She was with me. I put her in her stasis tube -- We launched when the --
answer: You were the only living thing found aboard that vessel.

question: Oh, God. Newt. It came with us.
answer: What came with you?

question: Listen -- there is a danger here. It came with me. How long have I been here?
answer: Almost two days --

question: Loose for two days. This planet could be overrun within the week. Look, there's a xenomorph -- An Alien creature. A killer. A monster. And now it's here. Calm down, Ripley. Okay, I was with a platoon of Colonial Marines on a mission to planetoid LV426. We left Earth six months ago - maybe a year --
answer: Wait a moment -- Leave us. Continue.

question: We launched in the Cruiser Sulaco from Gateway sub-orbital space station --
answer: Not possible.

question: What do you mean?
answer: When we left Earth seventy years ago, it was on the brink of a New Dark Age. Technology was on the verge of destroying the planet's environment. A computer virus was threatening to wipe away all recorded knowledge. There didn't seem to be any way it could be averted. In the almost forty years since we were towed out here in hypersleep, the news that came with occasional supply ships only got worse. Finally, the ships stopped coming. We had to resign ourselves to the fact that worst had come to pass, and the Earth no longer existed.

question: Uh...All right... Forget the Earth - How many people do you have here? Let's worry about them. Warn them --
answer: Your mind is troubled. You need to rest some more.

question: I don't need rest - I need to get to your people. You've got to get to them -- tell them about the alien --
answer: I have had enough for now.

question: Enough? Didn't you hear what I said? It could wipe out the entire population of this planet. It may have started already - Have there been any unusual deaths since I got here?
answer: No. And there won't be. Bolt it.

question: No. And there won't be. Bolt it.
answer: What is it -- What's wrong?

question: Your patient is in a dangerous mental state. Nobody gets in or out until I say so.
answer: But I. Her meals --

question: Nobody.
answer: Father, I don't understand --

question: Father, I don't understand --
answer: Brother John! You're here! The Abbot said you'd -- I need -- you're the medic --

question: What?!
answer: My Sandy -- she's ill --

question: Huh? A woman?
answer: Sandy. My ewe.

question: One of your sheep? Jesus Christ. Call a vet.
answer: Father Anselm was the vet.

question: You're no help. Okay, let me get my bag. All creatures great and small...
answer: I just gave her dinner and she keeled over.

question: So would I. It's freezing in here.
answer: Been using the wood from the walls for the fire in my cabin.

question: Haven't we all... May be pneumonia. Pitch some of that hay around her. Stop this damn cold breeze. First, I'll -- Wait a minute...
answer: What is it?

question: I don't know. It's all over the ground. Some sort of --
answer: What?! WHAT?!

question: Yes, the ship brought it. Not evil. It brought the Alien. I told you, it's here.
answer: We know the name of the evil it brought. It brought technology. Technology to destroy our planet, as surely as it destroyed the Earth.

question: I was on the Earth less than a year ago. It's still there. People, cities, all still there!
answer: All dead.

question: It's still there!
answer: You could not have been on the Earth a year ago, because there is no Earth to be on -- for at least twenty years.

question: I had that wood earmaked for the Cloister next winter. Well, we might not get to the winter if we don't take care of this. By winter time we can start taking the penitent cells apart. No one in them. Neither are we -- Go ahead.
answer: This woman. Ripley. I tended her --

question: Yes, and you did a good job. You shouldn't feel responsible. You couldn't have known --
answer: Please, sir, let me finish. I feel that there may be something to what she says.

question: There isn't.
answer: I don't understand what you are doing.

question: This colony is my responsibility. I am protecting the colony.
answer: From what? This woman? You never gave her a chance. How can you be so sure you're right?

question: A better question is what makes you think I'm wrong?
answer: You didn't see this thing -- this demon -- Brother Graham and I -- we both saw it.

question: That's right. You both did. And what was it?
answer: I -- I don't know what it was. But I don't think Ripley was a party to it.

question: She admits she brought it.
answer: But she tried to warn us --

question: You know that's how the devil works. Deception.
answer: But I believe her. I don't know how to describe it -- A feeling.

question: You haven't seen a woman in thirty years. Where does this feeling originate, John?
answer: Here.

question: I believe you. But your feelings are fooling you.
answer: It's - It's her conviction. I just think --

question: Don't think. It's been a long night. For all of us. You really don't understand what you're dealing with here.
answer: That's what she said.

question: These are ideas which threaten the very system we live under. The creature is dead and the woman is gone. Forget them. Both. Go read. Go fishing. Go anywhere, but leave this alone.
answer: But I --

question: Alone. I'll get Philip to let Mattias into the Library, all right? For your own good, just stay out of this. I mean it.
answer: Yes, Father.

question: At the glass furnace. About to dip his blowing iron into the MOLTEN GLASS. John runs over to him. Almost knocks him over -- Hey! Watch it! What? What is it?
answer: I -- Abbot. Must --

question: John - relax. Take a deep breath - Christ, now I sound like you -- Is that it, John? Is it the book --?
answer: Yes. Devil.

question: Everything's gonna be fine. Now, let's see the --
answer: Don't humor me -- I'm --

question: Sure. Everything's gonna be fine... Wait -- JOHN!
answer: Can smell the dank air from the lower tunnels. He MUST go down -- The hard way. He climbs into the darkness...

question: Wherever I go. Thanks, but no thanks, Anthony.
answer: You waiting for meat? They don't bring me meat because they know I'm an android. Really don't need it. Bread's better for you anyway. Harder to digest, so it makes you feel fuller than you are.

question: Not hungry.
answer: Mmmm. Just a little crunchy.

question: Waste of time.
answer: You don't eat, you'll starve to death, girl.

question: That was the plan when they put me down here. And why should you care?
answer: Because I'm a synthetic person you don't think I can care?

question: Believe me, that's a discussion you don't want to have with me.
answer: You told me you had a bad experience and a good one with androids --

question: That's one of each. That means you could go either way. I'm tired of talking about this.
answer: You've still gotta eat. You gotta fight the bastards --

question: I'm tired of fighting. Maybe I'll be dead before he finds me. Maybe he won't get the satisfaction.
answer: He? You make it sound like this Alien has a personal score to settle with you. The biology you describe

question: And Androids usually aren't the prisoners of lunatics that believe they're ancient Greeks.
answer: Medieval Monks.

question: Whatever.
answer: And they've only chose to live the life style, they don't believe they're -- What's that?

question: And they've only chose to live the life style, they don't believe they're -- What's that?
answer: Ripley!

question: Hey -- you knocking -- cut it out -- You're going to wake everybody up. Brother John?
answer: Anthony? Thought you dead fifteen years.

question: Made too good for that. What're you doing?
answer: I -- I'm looking -- the Abbot --

question: It never ends.
answer: It must be able to take on some of the characteristics of the animal it grows in. Maybe they are from some sort of aggressive soldier race -- warring parties drop the eggs on opposing planets --

question: And the alien takes on the form of the creature that finds it, assuming that animal is the dominant life form on the planet. So when it gestates in a man --
answer: It's a biped. In a sheep or cow, a quadroped.

question: Shit. I just didn't think it could do that to animals.
answer: Wait a minute - I thought you were the expert on this monster.

question: Is that the only reason you came to get me out? Because I knew about this thing?
answer: Yes. I mean no. I mean, that was part of it. Look. I never thought you were wrong. I was wrong not to say anything. I was afraid to speak up. It's hard to be a monk, you know?

question: Thank you. If anything, you're honest.
answer: We all are. Took vows.

question: I don't know about the Abbot.
answer: I'm sure he thinks what he did was right.

question: Is that speaking up for someone?
answer: No. Charity.

question: Get to my ship and get off this Satellite.
answer: We can't.

question: We can't what?
answer: Leave Arceon. Can't leave the library --

question: A Tape Library?
answer: Books.

question: So?
answer: The reason we are out here. Like the Monks who guarded Monastery Libraries on remote islands off England during the First Plague --

question: There must be books on other colonies --
answer: Some of these books survived the burning of the Libraries of Alexandria. They contain knowledge that exists in no other record. Their value is unestimable. We're supposed to protect them.

question: And what does an android have to do with all this?
answer: He's a spy.

question: To the Company.
answer: They sold the technology. A movement to live simply was quickly twisted by Federal agents into a political movement against the Company-controlled World Government. Too much was at stake.

question: Too much profit.
answer: We were sentenced as political dissidents. This orbiter is our gulag. All the men were packed up with all our books, and towed into space. Ten thousand men. The eldest died very quickly.

question: The Company had such a sense of irony. Sending you out on this wooden tub.
answer: I was placed among them as a sensor. Keeps tabs on the movement.

question: So how'd they find out about you?
answer: I told them. After the supply ship's stopped coming I saw no point in keeping up the charade. Since I was a sort of walking reminder of technology, they cast me down.

question: Well, you start appreciating him more than me and I'll find a way to shut you down, capisce, Andy? How do we get up?
answer: There are ladders.

question: Five miles with the Alien between us and there? Good luck, boys.
answer: You can't --

question: Can't what? Not help you go to your deaths? I've had my fill of that.
answer: I need you. I can't do it alone.

question: How about something we can make weapons from? Do you have anything like that -- any modern things here?
answer: We renounced technology. It was those things that caused the Plague.

question: This is a man-made planet. Something has to be recirculating your air, your water.
answer: God?

question: Please.
answer: I don't know. I just took it for granted.

question: Most people do. Without some sort of technology we haven't got a chance.
answer: There is technology. A room. A Technology room. Fresh air and water come out.

question: An atmosphere processing plant --
answer: The heart and lungs of Arceon.

question: Where is it?
answer: One level beneath the underground sea.

question: What?
answer: Those things you said before -- I read about it in psychology books. Sometimes when people outlive someone they cared for, they transfer some of the guilt for that person's death to themselves.

question: I got a belly full of that from the Psychtechs when I was on Earth. Yeah. "Survivor Guilt syndrome," or something like that. But that's not what I was thinking about. I was thinking about my "friend" up there. He was on the pod. He killed Newt but not me. Why not me? It's almost like he's playing with me. Maybe they have some sort of race memory. Maybe he knows what I did to his "mother." That's why he didn't just kill me. That would be too easy. He has to torment me.
answer: You make it sound human.

question: Hell, I don't know what it is.
answer: I think I do.

question: Breathing heavy - opens his eyes -- He's staring right into Ripley's face. Less than an inch away. He's laying on top of her. She's breathing heavy too. A long, uncomfortable moment.
answer: Thanks.

question: You're welcome.
answer: I'm all right.

question: Dreams.
answer: Androids can't dream...

question: That's probably what they thought when they built me. But my brain is cyber- organic - patterned after the human brain - it functions the same way a human brain does. It accumulates random images and sensations during waking hours, but unlike the human brain that sloughs them off during sleep --
answer: Androids don't sleep.

question: Right. Maybe they've fixed this on later models, but I don't. Do you know what happens to the human brain when it is deprived of sleep? It starts to run off the dreams while you're awake, as hallucinations. Same thing with me. For twenty years I absorbed data on this planetoid. A little after we lost contact with Earth the visions started. They thought I was insane. I had to explain that it was because I was an android. They liked that even less.
answer: What did you see?

question: Stay with him.
answer: No. We all need rest. You especially. Doctor's orders. Besides, you see what happens when you get ahead of us. We should stay together.

question: All right. He's still above us, anyway.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I've faced this evil twice before - I guess I've gotten sensitive to it -- You're really a Doctor?
answer: See my bag?

question: What's that book?
answer: Just a book.

question: I don't buy "just a book" from a guy who says we can't leave the planet without the library.
answer: It's just... a medical book I might need.

question: You don't have any food in there, do you?
answer: Only if you can eat bandages.

question: You all right?
answer: Aces.

question: You weren't hurt when I landed on you? Bruised a rib?
answer: Are you sure you're a doctor?

question: Sort of. My father passed on when we first came here. The Abbey's Physician - Father Anselm - took me in. He really raised me -- Taught me what he could before he passed away. He was schooled on Earth.
answer: Well, I'm just hungry.

question: You haven't eaten since I took you out of your tube.
answer: You did that... You burned yourself on the escape pod. Thank you, I guess.

question: Blood.
answer: Getting close...

question: The Abbot.
answer: Father --

question: I do what I have to do to keep the Brotherhood together. We all gave up believing in Earth a long time ago. How do you think they would feel if told their exiled was in vain? That the holocaust they were trying to avoid never occured? Those men up there have grown to live with it.
answer: And with you as their leader.

question: You threatened the status quo.
answer: So you, protector of knowledge and truth, lied to them.

question: Only about you. The rest I still believe. If Earth still orbits its sun there is no way it could have survived being reduced to Barbarism.
answer: You're as bad as the Company.

question: The Organism.
answer: The Devil.

question: Bringing up the rear, puts his walking stick down -- SNAPP!!! Everybody stops at the sound.
answer: What was that?

question: Man trap. In case anyone tried to get in and tamper with the technology.
answer: What do we do?

question: What do we do?
answer: Don't move. Don't breath.

question: We can't just stand here and wait.
answer: Floor's too unstable to try to walk around them.

question: John - what are you doing?
answer: He's thinking like a leader. Everyone

question: He's thinking like a leader. Everyone
answer: Brother.

question: Brother. Let's go.
answer: I just - are you allright?

question: Tied. Without sleep, food -- I just feel my age. Figuring hyperspace time, I'm almost a hundred.
answer: Hello? I think this is it.

question: Technology.
answer: Yeah - a hundred years ago. An antique.

question: Go ahead.
answer: Go ahead and what?

question: Open the door, woman.
answer: I'll get to it, but listen to me -- you may dress like you're living in the middle ages but you can't treat me like your chambermaid, or whatever Monks had.

question: She's breathing heavy. She's wearing a sweat soaked tank top. Her eyes flit from side to side. Then up. Then down. She pokes the weapon out ahead of her and moves into the pod. She silently crosses the distance to Newt's sleep tube: No. NO! I beat you! I beat you mother fucker!!
answer: I thought we'd lost you.

question: What are you writing?
answer: Last will and testament. Just kidding.

question: Is he --?
answer: Resting. He'll be fine.

question: Do you see what you've delivered us into?
answer: Yeah. Lead me not into temptation to kick your -- ahh -- Oh shit. Where is the Big Boy -?

question: On the other side of that door. Waiting for us to starve to death.
answer: It's playing with us. It could get in here any time it wants.

question: BASTARD!! It came out of his fucking head!
answer: I didn't have to see that to know what that means.

question: He sent him to us. That bastard outside. I can't get away from him. He's fucking with my mind. He's my punishment!
answer: I'm confused. Before you said it came out of the torso, not the head --

question: I don't feel like a discussion of Alien biology.
answer: Ripley, don't --

question: I should just wait for the air to run out...
answer: I believe - I know - that we can win -- there is an answer in our books.

question: Your books? Your books are gone, Brother. Your world is gone. Once that thing starts to lay its eggs, all your brothers - if they aren't already - are dead.
answer: If that's true, then all of us, the books, are consigned to ashes.

question: What?
answer: There are several inconsistancies between this and the other Aliens you described.

question: Give it up.
answer: I think this is important. This may help us fight it. The creature that I fought in the hall - when I first saw it, it had camoflaged itself to look like wood.

question: Wood? When I saw it in my room it looked the way it did before -- black, mechanical -- unless that was a dream.
answer: I don't think it was. I think that this creature, if it is the efficient predator that you say it is, has the ability to adapt to its environment.

question: Then the reason they've always looked the same to me is that I only ever saw them in the same environment.
answer: Or this may be an as yet unseen stage of development -- you saw a queen -- This could be like a King ant -- more highly advanced than the drone, bred for survival -?

question: How does this explain the thing that came out of the ewe's chest? The Abbot's head?
answer: Maybe it can deposit different types of eggs. The chest burster is probably dormant until the host eats - The first one I ever saw came out of Kane after he started to eat -- No.

question: No what?
answer: No, we're not beat yet, Father --

question: Brother --
answer: Brother. Not yet. If he's taunting me, then maybe we can use that. We can beat this bastard. We can get to my ship. We can live.

question: Brother. Not yet. If he's taunting me, then maybe we can use that. We can beat this bastard. We can get to my ship. We can live.
answer: Don't have second thoughts. Blind and crippled I would only slow you down. Give him time to figure out what you're doing. Just leave me my staff.

question: Okay. Good luck.
answer: Ripley, I know. Good luck.

question: Sit tight. He could be waiting on the other side of that door. We might not get ten feet before he kills the three of us.
answer: We had better go, then. Must be day on the surface of the planet.

question: Where is the light coming from?
answer: Mirrors. Reflect the outside light down great shafts -- through lenses. That's what they make in the glass factory. Lenses. Look -- Opens to the surface. Water flows in and out. I don't know how. There's one at either end. I came down on the other side.

question: What do we do?
answer: We cross.

question: Your hands okay?
answer: They'll be fine. You've been on a boat before.

question: I was a warrant officer on a ship -- but I did all my sailing in space.
answer: Father Anselm used to take me on his coracle when I was little.

question: How old were you when they towed this satellite out here?
answer: Five. The Abbot said they put us to sleep for the thirty years it took to get here. We've had almost forty more. Until now.

question: What happened to your mother?
answer: Never had one. I mean, never knew her. I mean, I did, once. She left my father when he joined the movement. If she hadn't I wouldn't be here. They kept the other children with the women, on Earth. That was too long ago now. Like a dream.

question: Did you know that I was a mother?
answer: The girl in the ship with -?

question: No. On Earth. I never mentioned my daughter. My daughter. I have - had I guess, by now - a daughter on Earth. Kathy. She was nine when I signed on to the Nostromo. Mommy will be home before you know it I said. My shares would have set us up good. Then I lost sixty years floating around in a rescue pod. Thanks to the Alien. I came home to face a bitter, 70 year old woman. My daughter. A little girl who's mother never came home.
answer: Jesus Christ.

question: They said I should have been happy to be alive. Funny, huh? That's why I went back the second time. Not so I could fight it -- You can't fight it -- So I could let it kill me.
answer: You didn't choose to get lost in space.

question: Thanks for the try Father --
answer: Brother.

question: Brother, but I'm not looking for absolution. I couldn't be a good mother to my daughter. I couldn't be a good mother to Newt. But I can be a good mother to you. I can make sure you survive. Blood.
answer: From the levels above. He must have slaughtered all --

question: Don't think about it. Don't think about what's up there. Just row. Holy shit.
answer: There's Andrew. And Raphael. Peter...

question: Stop. How far?
answer: We're right below the Abbey now. This is the glassworks. They have tools here -- Kyle --

question: We're right below the Abbey now. This is the glassworks. They have tools here -- Kyle --
answer: Can't see my baby. Don't see my baby. Bay be.

question: Kyle. Brother Kyle.
answer: Cards on the floor, fifty two pickup. Black king on red queen, put the ace up --

question: Keep singing, my friend.
answer: Pulls a blowing iron from the rack. Feels its weight and balance. A reasonable weapon. She crosses to John.

question: I killed him. I'm a doctor and I killed him.
answer: You had to. You're supposed to end suffering. Let's get the hell out of here. He's made a mess.

question: No. He hasn't been up here yet. I did this. Here - philosophy - we'll start here -- Mattias! He waited. Ripley, this is Mattias. My dog. Good fellow.
answer: I'm glad. Really. But we've probably only got a few minutes before this entire place goes up in flames. Just grab whatever books you want and --
